DescriptionData.Title: Acetyl L-Carnitine (ALCAR) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Due to the association that ALCAR has with the specific acetyl group that it belongs to, it is known for the great variety of benefits it provides related to overall mental health. It is also an antioxidant.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Arginine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Arginine is one of the rare amino acids that is considered semi-essential; although the body can manufacture appropriate amounts, every once in a while it may be necessary to supplement it.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Arginine Base Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Arginine is one of the rare amino acids that is considered semi-essential; although the body can manufacture appropriate amounts, every once in a while it may be necessary to supplement it.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Arginine a-Ketoglutarate (AAKG) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Arginine is one of the rare amino acids that is considered semi-essential; although the body can manufacture appropriate amounts, every once in a while it may be necessary to supplement. This is particularly true for many athletes.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Alanine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Alanine is an amino acid, making it popular to supplement among athletes.

DescriptionData.Title: Glycine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Glycine has a host of different benefits and roles in the body. For more information, additional research is recommended for those debating if supplementation is right for them.

DescriptionData.Title: Glutathione Reduced Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Regular Glutathione can be found naturally from a variety of sources such as fruits, vegetables and various meats including fish. Sources particularly rich in Glutathione content are asparagus, walnuts and avocado.

DescriptionData.Title: EDTA Disodium Powder
DescriptionData.Description: In addition to being sold as a food additive, it is also present in several pharmaceutical products such as soaps, shampoos and cosmetics. It is both odorless an colorless and works by binding with various minerals and heavy metals. Although the FDA has approved Calcium Disodium for various uses, additional research is suggested before supplementation.

DescriptionData.Title: EDTA Calcium Disodium Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although the FDA has approved Calcium Disodium for various uses, additional research is suggested before supplementation.

DescriptionData.Title: DL-Phenylalanine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although DL-Phenylalanine provides several health benefits related to mood and pain management, additional research on the supplement is encouraged for those interested.

DescriptionData.Title: DL-Methionine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Once consumed, the body combines DL-Methionine with ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate) where they goes on to produce SAMe. This is a requirement of at least 40 different biochemical reactions that are necessary towards sustaining life, and it is also indirectly present in a lot more.

DescriptionData.Title: D-Aspartic Acid (DAA) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This supplement is popular among both athletes and men. For those debating supplementation, additional research on its benefits is recommended.

DescriptionData.Title: Creatine Monohydrate (Micronized) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Supplements of Creatine Monohydrate are constantly being studied by nutritionists for their energy creation properties.

DescriptionData.Title: Creatine Ethyl Ester HCL (CEE) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Creatine has become quite popular in recent years for various sporting and athletic activities for its various benefits.

DescriptionData.Title: BCAA 2:1:1 (Branch Chain Amino Acids) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: These amino acids are referred to as Branch Chain Amino Acids because they have a chemical structure that separates them from the rest of the amino acid family. In addition, these BCAAs make up 40% of total body protein content and represent around 15 to 25% of total protein intake overall.

DescriptionData.Title: Beta Alanine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Beta Alanine is chiefly useful in increasing endurance, but consumers are encouraged to research the supplement to see if it is right for them.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Arginine L-Pyroglutamate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Arginine is one of the rare amino acids that is considered semi-essential; although the body can manufacture appropriate amounts, every once in a while it may be necessary to supplement it.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Aspartic Acid Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Though the body usually produces enough, choosing to take an Aspartic Acid supplement can help increase fatigue resistance and help athletes perform longer.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Carnitine Base Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Carnitine is considered conditionally essential, meaning that there are certain conditions a person can undergo which might make supplementation or dietary changes necessary to keep up Carnitine levels.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Carnosine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Carnosine can be manufactured by the body to some extent through the bond that takes place during the synthesis of alanine and histidine. It may be found in many different bodily tissues including skeletal muscles, the stomach, brain and skin, among others.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Citrulline Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Citrulline helps athletes heal after long bouts of exercise in a similar fashion to Creatine, but does so without the occasional side effects like bloating and cramps. It is also a precursor to Arginine.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Citrulline DL-Malate 1:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This compound may help tired muscles recover fast from fatigue and physical exertion. This particular supplement includes a 1:1 ratio of Citrulline and Malate.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Cysteine HCL Monohydrate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Cysteine is conditionally essential. This means that the body generally produces enough on its own; however, during exercise, much of it can be depleted. This may require supplementation.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Glutamine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Because Glutamine is an energy source, it can be significantly reduced once exercise has taken place. Levels will remain low until the person has completely recovered from the exercise.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Histidine Base Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Histidine is generally found in foods with high protein content such as meats, dairy, wheat, and soy.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Histidine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Histidine is generally found in foods with high protein content such as meats, dairy, wheat, and soy.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Isoleucine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Isoleucine is one of the five most abundant amino acids that can be found in the skeletal muscles and makes up a total of about 1/8 of all proteins in the body. L-Isoleucine is considered essential because the body cannot produce it on its own. It must be supplemented to get its benefits.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Leucine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Valine, Leucine, and Isoleucine make up one of the chains called Branch Chain Amino Acids. They make up a large amount of the body’s total protein structure. Leucine is one of the main ways that the body is able to produce energy. This makes it very highly sought after by athletes. For this particular chain, it is best to take two parts Leucine, one part Valine and one part Isoleucine.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Lysine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Lysine helps in protein synthesis and tissue health. Most foods, including meats, and vegetables with high levels of protein are also good sources of Lysine.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Methionine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This amino acid can be found in large amounts in fish, beans, eggs, Brazil nuts, lentils, garlic, yogurt, onions, various meats and some other plants and seeds.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Norvaline Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Norvaline is credited as being an inhibitor that keeps Arginine functioning. Arginine can be found in high concentrations in the skin.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Ornithine a-ketoglutarate OKG Powder
DescriptionData.Description: While the body generally produces enough Alpha-Ketoglutaric Acid that supplementation is not needed, it is considered conditionally essential during intense exercise.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Ornithine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Along with Arginine and Carnitine, this supplement is frequently used during exercise.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Phenylalanine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although this supplement is believed to help maintain overall wellness, additional research on its benefits are recommended.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Proline Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Though Proline is synthesized by the body, the amount that is actually produced is often not enough. It is mainly found through dietary means in animal products. Vegetarians may need to supplement in order to get the correct amount. Proline also works in tandem with Vitamin C and Lysine to help maintain the integrity of collagen.

Proline may be reduced after exercise, which is why some energy drinks contain trace amounts of the amino acid.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Serine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Serine can assist in the metabolic process and the creation of Creatine (which helps with the growth and maintenance of muscles). It also helps to synthesize Tryptophan.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Theanine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Since green tea in the U.S. generally contains less than 10mg Theanine, very few people actually see its effects in action. This makes concentrated supplementation beneficial. If taken in higher doses, Theanine may create feelings of drowsiness and deeper sleep.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Threonine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Since Threonine is naturally found in animal-based products, vegans and vegetarians may benefit from supplementation as their dietary alternative.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Tryptophan Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
In order for Tryptophan to work correctly, there needs to be adequate amounts of Vitamin B6 in the body. It also needs adequate amounts of Vitamin C, B9 and Magnesium.

Tryptophan is generally known for its high levels in turkey and is cited as one of the reasons so many people become sleepy after Thanksgiving dinner. However, Tryptophan is just as common in other meats.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Tyrosine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: While Tyrosine may be considered nonessential and does not necessarily need to be supplemented, there are many dietary sources that Tyrosine may be derived from, such as almonds, pumpkin seeds, different types of dairy, bananas, lima beans and sesame seeds.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Valine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: About 1/4 of overall protein intake in a standard diet is in the form of BCAAs, and L-Valine is considered an essential amino acid because the body cannot provide significant enough amounts on its own. It must be found through supplementation or other dietary means.

DescriptionData.Title: N-Acetyl L-Carnosine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Carnosine can be manufactured by the body to some extent through the bond that takes place during the synthesis of Alanine and Histidine. Carnosine may be found in many different bodily tissues including skeletal muscles, the stomach, brain and skin, among others.

DescriptionData.Title: N-Acetyl L-Cysteine (NAC) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: NAC is a more bioavailable form of the original L-Cysteine, another kind of sulfur-based amino acid type. Unfortunately, NAC cannot be found in the diet and needs to be supplemented in order to gain the full benefits.

DescriptionData.Title: N-Acetyl L-Tyrosine (NALT) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Tyrosine is a nonessential amino acid, which means that the body alone can manufacture large enough amounts that it need not be supplemented through dietary means. However, a deficiency may be cause for supplementation.

DescriptionData.Title: Taurine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Taurine may aid in the transport of nutrients such as Calcium, Sodium, Potassium and Magnesium through the cell wall. Functioning similarly to Creatine, athletes like to use Taurine for its many benefits.

DescriptionData.Title: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C) Crystalized Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
HEALTH BENEFITS PROVIDED BY ASCORBIC ACID POWDER

For the many benefits of Vitamin C, consumers are encouraged to do their independent research.

DescriptionData.Title: N-Acetyl L-Glutamine Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Glutamine is considered a nonessential acid, which means that the body can naturally manufacture it without supplementation. Because Glutamine is an energy source, however, it can be significantly reduced once exercise has taken place. Levels will stay at a low until the person has completely recovered from the exercise.

DescriptionData.Title: Ascorbyl Palmitate (Vitamin C Ester) Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Health Benefits Provided by Ascorbyl Palmitate

Ascorbyl Palmitate has many of the same essential roles as Vitamin C and is intended to promote overall wellness.

DescriptionData.Title: Beta Carotene 1% (Provitamin A) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Beta-Carotene contains Vitamin A and has a yellow-orange pigment that gives the distinctive color to certain fruits and vegetables such as pumpkins, carrots, sweet potatoes, oranges, tomatoes, bananas and squash. It is also the pigment that gives the bright orange color to cooked lobsters and the pink color to salmon and flamingos.

DescriptionData.Title: Broccoli Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Supplementation of broccoli extract is intended to promote overall good health.

DescriptionData.Title: Calcium Ascorbate (Vitamin C) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Calcium Ascorbate Buffered Vitamin C combines the benefits of both compounds.

DescriptionData.Title: Choline DL-Bitartrate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although it is not actually a B vitamin, it is sometimes considered to be a part of this complex because it operates in conjunction with various types of B vitamins.

DescriptionData.Title: Cinnamon Bark Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Cinnamon Extract contains catechins, or antioxidants that can also be commonly found in other healthy things like teas.

DescriptionData.Title: Coenzyme Q10 (COQ10) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Unlike other supplements, Coenzyme Q10 can actually be taken both as a dietary supplement and also as a topical rub in order for the intended effects to be experienced. When Coenzyme Q10 is taken as a supplement, it is best to also supplement Vitamin E, C or both at the same time along with it, as these will both have the effect of optimizing the supplement’s overall performance.

DescriptionData.Title: Curcumin 95% Natural Turmeric Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: In addition to its benefits as a natural supplement, turmeric is also used as a culinary spice and is popular in many eastern regions.

DescriptionData.Title: Ellagic Acid 90% Galla Chinensis Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Antioxidants from sources such as Ellagic Acid are extremely important because they help to slow the progress of and neutralize free radicals, harmful molecules that result when nutrients are improperly metabolized and are known for causing damage to healthy cells.

Health Benefits Provided By Ellagic Acid

Aside from its ability to neutralize free radicals, Ellagic Acid is a detoxification aid and can really clean out the liver through direct support of enzymes which promote this cleaning process and also go on to protect cells in the liver from future damage.

DescriptionData.Title: Garlic Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: There are many other active ingredients in Garlic besides Allicin, such as Allinase, Myrosinase, Peroxidase, various Vitamins of the B group, Vitamin C and other antioxidants. Garlic also has a small but modest mineral content, including Iron, Zinc and Copper, in its makeup.

DescriptionData.Title: Grape Seed Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: While Vitamins C and E are thought to be great sources of antioxidants, the antioxidants present in these nutrients are usually excreted from the body not long after consumption. However, the antioxidants provided by Grape Seed Extract can stay in the body up to three days.

DescriptionData.Title: Green Tea Pure Extract 50% EGCG Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Since Green Tea is not a fermented product, it has high Polyphenol content. These Polyphenols have antioxidant properties. Green Tea also contains Epigallocatechin (EGCG), a type of compound that can be found in such diverse areas as green tea, bananas and pomegranates.

DescriptionData.Title: Green Tea 50% Polyphenols Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Since Green Tea is not a fermented product, it has high Polyphenol content. These Polyphenols have antioxidant properties. Green Tea also contains Epigallocatechin (EGCG), a type of compound that can be found in such diverse areas as green tea, bananas and pomegranates.

DescriptionData.Title: Inositol Hexaphosphate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Inositol Hexaphosphate is part of the B-vitamin chain. IP6, the direct derivative of Inositol Hexaphosphate, is a necessary ingredient in the tissues of many types of legumes, with soybeans having the highest concentration. This makes soybeans one of the greatest sources of nutritionally derived IP6 along with other high fiber foods such as cereals, beans, corn, tofu, oatmeal, brown rice and peanuts, just to name a few. Inositol Hexaphosphate may be effective as an antioxidant as well.

DescriptionData.Title: Lutein 5% Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This supplement is frequently used to provide support to the retina and to assume its role as an antioxidant.

DescriptionData.Title: N,N-Dimethyl Glycine HCL (DMG) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Since Dimethyl Glycine (DMG) is so closely related to Glycine, it is also an important component in the production of energy for the body. In addition, Glycine promotes good digestive health and helps maintain immune system health. It also functions as an antioxidant.

DescriptionData.Title: Para-AminoBenzoic Acid (PABA) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: PABA can serve as a provitamin to several types of bacteria and is even referred to as Vitamin Bx informally, despite the fact that it is not classified as either a vitamin or a nutrient with essential properties. This is because it is included in the family of the Vitamin B complex, but is not, itself, part of the normal Vitamin B chain.

DescriptionData.Title: Pine Bark Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Pine Bark Extract can be absorbed by the body in less than 20 minutes, and its effects can last for up to three days. However, Pine Bark Extract actually works well when combined with Vitamin C to help the body recycle and reuse Vitamin E.

DescriptionData.Title: Pomegranate Extract Powder - (40% Ellagic Acid)
DescriptionData.Description: This particular extract is derived from pomegranates and contains at least 40% Ellagic Acid.

DescriptionData.Title: Portulaca Oleracea (Purslane) Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Purslane is also one of the few non-meat sources for Omega-3 fatty acids. In fact, it has higher amounts of Alpha-Linoleic acid than spinach.As an added bonus, it is rich in vitamins, minerals, amino acids and antioxidants.

DescriptionData.Title: R-Alpha Lipoic Acid (R-ALA) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: ALA also assists in recycling various other antioxidants and may contribute to increased energy levels.

DescriptionData.Title: Resveratrol (Pure) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: The most popular Resveratrol supplements that can be bought today are usually using Resveratrol derived from Japanese Knotweed. This represents one of the best original sources for extraction, since it contains the substance in such high amounts.

DescriptionData.Title: Rutin Powder
DescriptionData.Description: As the body is unable to produce Rutin on its own, it must be supplemented through dietary means. When taken with Vitamin C, bioflavonoids increase in efficiency and effectiveness. Rutin can be found in a variety of different sources, including red apples, tea, green leafy veggies, citrus fruits and onions.

DescriptionData.Title: Vitamin E 1300 IU Oil
DescriptionData.Description:
In fact, the Vitamin E which is found naturally comes in not 1, but 8 different forms which each have their own importance in the body's biological processes. Since of the 8 forms of Vitamin E half are Tocopherols and the other half are Tocotrienols, this product contains large quantities of alpha, delta, and gamma Tocopherols and a few beta.

Alpha-Tocopherol is the most effective of these forms in terms of its tendency and ability to be absorbed by the body. It is located throughout the human blood stream and is known for being both the most active type of Vitamin E in the body and also the only naturally occurring kind of Alpha-Tocopherol. There is some research which remarks on the possibility for the effectiveness of Alpha-Tocopherol to be increased when in the presence of other tocopherols; however this research has yet to be proven for certain. As far as the comparison between natural and synthetic forms of Tocopherols, the competition isn't even close. Natural Tocopherol beats out synthetic Vitamin E in terms of retention as well as absorption every time.

Vitamin E can be found in many different skin creams because it is known for promoting skin health and elasticity. It can even increase the healing rate when a burn or cut has been sustained if it is applied in a timely manner. Vitamin E does not only protect the skin on the outside though, it also protects it at a deeper cellular level by keeping cell membranes well protected and giving them a defense against oxidation.

Vitamin E is absorbed into the blood via the lymph, which in turn takes it from the stomach just as is the case with bile and fats. Once it is in the blood, it can be transferred to the liver to be stored for later use. There the Tocopherols can use the liver as a base to send out agents to prevent free radicals from harming the body. As it is found in various supplements, Vitamin E is actually just Alpha-Tocopherol Acetate which above all, allows it to continue its antioxidant functions despite how it is absorbed and digested.

Vitamin E is a relatively common dietary supplement and is sold as such. It can even be derived naturally from a few different foods. Sometimes it is even present in foods as an additive. It is often prized particularly for its effectiveness as an antioxidant.

Free radicals are merely molecules with unshared electrons. These electrons are known for retaining a high level of energy and react very quickly with Reactive Oxygen Species, which are sometimes referred to as ROS for short. These ROS are formed during the simple metabolic process of transforming food into energy, and it is the job of the antioxidant to protect cells from the harmful effects of ROS. These molecules are also produced in the body as a result of exposure to cigarette smoke air pollution, and high levels of ultraviolet radiation from the sun.

This type of antioxidant works by stopping the production of ROS that occur when fats are being oxidized. There are a few different chronic diseases that are associated with free radicals and at this moment, scientists are studying whether the ability of Vitamin E to hinder these processes may actually have the capacity to prevent these diseases from occurring in the first place.

It is no surprise that Vitamin E also has a connection to immune system fortification given its importance as an antioxidant. However, it also has a link to various other types of metabolic processes including gene expression and cell signaling.

Health Benefits Provided By Vitamin E Oil 1300 IU/g

The most important role that Vitamin E has in the body is to keep up the integrity of cellular structure and prevent damage to the skin while also promoting healing of the skin after it has already been damaged. Vitamin E is also revered for its ability to prevent or at least slow down the oxidation process of fats and other types of nutrients.

Vitamin E is not only able to protect the skin, but also provides a protective membrane around the eyes, liver, testes, and breast; the parts of the body that are most prone to oxidation.

One thing that seems to be true for most antioxidants is that they tend to work well with other antioxidants. This means that when taken in conjunction with Vitamin C, Beta-Carotene, etc., the effects of each antioxidant will actually be magnified.

Vitamin E may have a strong effect on the elasticity of the skin, but it also has this same effect on arterial elasticity. This means that blood can flow, free of obstruction, and keep the arteries from being clogged.

One particularly threatening aspect of oxidation is its potential to deconstruct and damage DNA, but this troubling aspect can be prevented when Vitamin E is present.

DescriptionData.Title: Vitamin E 700IU Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Alpha-Tocopherol is the most effective of these forms in terms of its tendency and ability to be absorbed by the body. It is located throughout the human blood stream and is known for being both the most active type of Vitamin E in the body and also the only naturally occurring kind of Alpha-Tocopherol.

Vitamin E can also be found in many different skin creams because it is known for promoting skin health and elasticity.

DescriptionData.Title: Zinc Gluconate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Those with a deficiency may want to consider supplementation of Zinc.

DescriptionData.Title: Zinc Oxide Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Those with a deficiency may want to consider supplementation of Zinc.

DescriptionData.Title: Betaine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Betaine is a byproduct that is obtained during the metabolism of Choline in the body, and it can also be naturally found in different foods such as wheat, sugar beets, spinach and other sources rich in protein.

DescriptionData.Title: Chlorella Blue-Green Algae Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
This algae is believed to be about 2 billion years old and was one of the first plants to have anything that could be called a defined nucleus in its cellular structure.The insides of the algae are chock full of nutrients, including Vitamin A, Vitamin K, Folic acid, Vitamin B2, Manganese and Iodine.

The question about the difference between Chlorella Algae and Spirulina Algae is often brought up, since the two are very similar. Chlorella Algae has higher Iron content than Spirulina, which can be a benefit or a drawback, depending on the individual needs of the person taking it.

DescriptionData.Title: Vitamin A Palmitate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Normally, Vitamin A is highly unstable alone. This is why it is reacted along with Methyl Palmitate. It functions as a simple antioxidant, protecting the body against harm from free radicals.

DescriptionData.Title: Phytosterol (Beta Sitosterol) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Phytosterol is a type of additive commonly found in margarine and alternative foods that are meant to help lower cholesterol levels.

DescriptionData.Title: Betaine Anhydrous Trimethylglycine (TMG) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Those interested in supplementing TMG powder are encouraged to research its benefits and potential side effects.

DescriptionData.Title: Nattokinase Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Vitamin K, which is necessary in bone building and in the bond between calcium and protein, is also a component in Nattokinase and other fermented vegetables.

DescriptionData.Title: Niacin (Vitamin B3) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Niacin is an excellent supplement for vegetarians, vegans and people who frequently consume alcohol. This is because diets that are low on meat are also low on Niacin, since some of the largest stores come from tryptophan.

DescriptionData.Title: Red Yeast Rice Extract (RYR) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Use of Red Yeast Rice goes as far back as 800 A.D., which is when it was first documented as being used. Notably, however, this product is not meant to cure any disease, but merely to promote general well-being. Red Yeast Rice Extract also contains flavonoids, essential antioxidants.

DescriptionData.Title: Bearberry Leaf Extract 4:1 (Uva Ursi) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This supplement also contains trace nutrients such as Vitamin A, Manganese, Iron, Silicon, and Selenium, all of which are essential for good health. This product may assist in promoting a healthy bladder.

DescriptionData.Title: Ginkgo Biloba Leaf Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Many tests and much research seem to indicate that there are many therapeutic benefits that come with taking Ginkgo Biloba, particularly when administered orally, which has caused it to become a popular herb in parts of Europe and the United States.

DescriptionData.Title: Hoodia Gordonii Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This powder is extracted directly from the Hoodia Gordonii plant and contains the P57 glycoside.

DescriptionData.Title: Horsetail Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Horsetail Extract contains Silica and flavonoids that act as antioxidants.

DescriptionData.Title: LongJack Extract 100:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Despite its recent popularity in western countries, it should be noted that this product has yet to receive FDA approval. As such, it is meant merely to support general well-being.

DescriptionData.Title: Dandelion Root Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Dandelions are also used in food and drink such as salads, wine, soups and teas. Occasionally, the roasted root is utilized as a coffee substitute. Since studies are still being conducted on the efficacy of this herbal extract, it is intended to promote overall health only.

DescriptionData.Title: Milk Thistle Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Milk Thistle is mainly made up of flavonoid compounds including isosilybin, silibinin and silymarin. The latter is the active ingredient in Milk Thistle and is the element that gives it its antioxidant properties.

DescriptionData.Title: Red Clover Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Red Clover has many different vitamins in it, including Vitamin C, Thiamine, and Niacin. It also has many minerals such as Calcium, Magnesium, and Chromium.

DescriptionData.Title: Rhodiola Rosea 3% Rosavin Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This supplement also has a generous helping of flavonoids (important antioxidant molecules), phenylpropanoids, essential oils and tannins.

DescriptionData.Title: Senna Leaf Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
The main purpose of Senna Leaf is as a laxative. The FDA has approved it for this use.

Senna contains chemicals called sennosides that stimulate the lining of the bowels.*

DescriptionData.Title: St John's Wort Powder
DescriptionData.Description: While this supplement has been linked to overall mental wellness, it is not intended to cure or prevent any disease.

DescriptionData.Title: White Willow Bark Extract 15% Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This extract is not intended to cure any specific illness or disease.

DescriptionData.Title: Calcium Carbonate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Those looking to supplement Calcium Carbonate for gastrointestinal discomfort or calcium deficiency are encouraged to research the compound to decide if it is right for them.

DescriptionData.Title: Calcium Citrate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Calcium Citrate is also recognized as a food additive. It can also be used as a preservative and a way to soften water.

DescriptionData.Title: Calcium Gluconate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This compound is notably not as chalky as some other Calcium supplements.

DescriptionData.Title: Caffeine (Synthetic) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This synthetic Caffeine powder is a particular kind of psychoactive stimulant called Trimexylxanthine, which is a part of the larger Xanthine family. These are naturally occurring and are found in a few different plants. Some of the most common sources of Caffeine are in sports drinks, energy drinks, tea, coffee, chocolate and most soft drinks.

DescriptionData.Title: DMAE-Bitartrate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: It has been found that by increasing levels of DMAE, this will also result in an increase in the levels of Choline in the brain. Even though Choline is not technically considered a vitamin, it works closely with the Vitamin B chain. It is a precursor to Acetylcholine.

DescriptionData.Title: Gamma Aminobutyric Acid (GABA) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: GABA is created from the reaction that takes place between GAD (Glutamic Acid Decarboxylase) and Vitamin B6. The body’s ability to actually continually produce GABA on its own is somewhat hampered by the fact that B-chain vitamins are required for all of the reactions that take place in order to form and eventually synthesize GABA.

DescriptionData.Title: Hyaluronic Acid (Na Hyaluronate) Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Hyaluronic Acid (Sodium Hyaluronate) is sometimes referred to as nature’s moisturizer due to its use as a bodily lubricant and the fact that it is one of the most hydrophilic molecules. It is used for a number of benefits.

This supplement can be taken orally or applied directly to the skin as a topical moisturizer. It is found in a wide selection of different beauty products and in some brands of makeup.

DescriptionData.Title: Inositol (Vitamin B8) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Inositol also helps promote healthy skin and cognitive functions.

DescriptionData.Title: Methylsulfonylmethane (MSM) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: About 34% of MSM is made up of sulfur, which is found in all the main structures of the body and is needed in some way by all of them. Though MSM can be found in the diet, it is often destroyed during the production sequence that goes into processed foods. Dehydrate foods also lose their MSM content. This is unfortunate, as MSM is a large supplier of raw materials that the body needs in order to function correctly.

DescriptionData.Title: Phenylethylamine HCL (PEA) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Overall, PEA is thought to promote feelings of well-being and contentment. It should be noted that the immediate effects of PEA HCL has a very short lifespan (lasting about 15 minutes), and this must be taken into account when supplementing.

DescriptionData.Title: Spirulina Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Due to the environment that this algae is usually found in, it is able to absorb both the rich amino acids and all of the vitamins present in the water, compacting them all in the form of a single-celled organism that can then be consumed to reap those benefits.

As a bonus, Spirulina acts as a great source of Vitamin B12, essential fatty acids, Beta Carotene, and Chlorophyll. Some of these elements are only present in high amounts in the diets of meat eaters, and other nutrients like Beta-Carotene and Chlorophyll act as antioxidants.

DescriptionData.Title: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Besides actively being involved in the process of creating energy, Riboflavin is also responsible for eventually being transformed into the coenzymes flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN). These coenzymes act upon adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and help transport it throughout the body.

Women who have been prescribed oral contraceptives and people who drink excessive amounts of alcohol may want to consider supplementing Riboflavin, as both of these elements may cause a reduction in the body’s ability to correctly absorb Riboflavin.

DescriptionData.Title: Potassium Iodate Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Iodine is needed in order for the Thyroid glands to function appropriately. These glands control the flow of certain very important hormones throughout the body, and without Iodine, the hormones will be incorrectly produced as Iodine is one of the essential ingredients that goes into these hormones. Far from merely controlling some nondescript hormones, the Thyroid controls metabolism to some extent, aids in the conversion between food and energy, keeps human growth and development in check, and it helps to keep body temperature at normal levels.

Not taking the correct amount of Iodine daily may result in Iodine deficiency which can then result in Hyperthyroidism. This causes the Thyroid to grow and expand in trying to keep up with the body’s demand for hormones. This could cause the development of a goiter that will be very visible on the body. Hyperthyroidism symptoms include a reduction in mental capabilities, depression, fatigue, dry or itchy skin, muscle cramps and pains, leg swelling, and heightened cholesterol levels.

If this disease continues untreated it may result in puffiness of the eyes, decrease in body temperature, heart rate reduction, general heart issues, and accumulation of fluid in or around the lungs, which can be very dangerous. In its most severe forms, Hyperthyroidism may even lead to a special kind of coma.

If a woman has Iodine deficiency while pregnant, this may significantly diminish the mental capabilities of the infant once it is born, along with speech problems, problems with movement, stunted growth, and general apathy (which is never a good sign in children). In essence, Iodine deficiency will lead to mental retardation in children. In fact, Iodine deficiency is generally thought to be one of the most common and preventable causes of brain damage. It can even lead to stillbirth and miscarriage if symptoms are severe in the pregnant women. Should this deficiency be corrected, studies have shown that children are more likely to survive.

A general American diet will have the necessary daily values of Iodine to function well, but in developing countries it has been found that about 30% of the population is subject to Iodine deficiency.

Health Benefits Provided by Potassium Iodate

Potassium Iodate is mainly used as a way of supplying the body with much needed Iodine. It is a much more important chemical than most people realize and is quite important for sustaining normal functioning and health.

DescriptionData.Description: Acai Berry has been used to promote overall health and a sense of wellness, as incorporating berries and similar foods into one’s diet may have beneficial results. Acai Berry extract is frequently used in cosmetic items such as shampoo due to its antioxidant content.

DescriptionData.Title: Green Tea Pure Extract 50% EGCG Capsules
DescriptionData.Description: Since Green Tea is not a fermented product, it has high Polyphenol content. These Polyphenols have antioxidant properties. Green Tea also contains Epigallocatechin (EGCG), a type of compound that can be found in such diverse areas as green tea, bananas and pomegranates.

DescriptionData.Title: Acai Berry Extract 4:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Acai Berry has been used to promote overall health and a sense of wellness, as incorporating berries and similar foods into one’s diet may have beneficial results. Acai Berry extract is frequently used in cosmetic items such as shampoo due to its antioxidant content.

DescriptionData.Title: Creatinol-O-Phosphate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Creatinol-O-Phosphate should not be supplemented as a replacement of Creatine. It is possible to stack Creatinol-O-Phosphate and Creatine Monohydrate together to enhance the effects of each.

DescriptionData.Title: Coconut Oil 1000 mg Softgels
DescriptionData.Description: Coconut Oil promotes overall wellness, believed to be beneficial for both brain and heart health. Though perfectly safe to consume, it is always advisable to discuss with a physician.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Glutamic Acid Powder
DescriptionData.Description: L-Glutamic Acid is also used as a food seasoning, recognized for its savory umami taste. This substance should not be confused with monosodium glutamate (MSG), which is chemically produced and toxic in larger quantities. L-Glutamic Acid is bound to protein, making it safe to consume.

DescriptionData.Title: Grass-Fed Whey Protein Isolate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Whey is a very rich source of protein, which accounts for 80% of its total weight. This protein powder is a rich source of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), essential amino acids that are largely found in muscle tissues.

DescriptionData.Title: Casein Protein Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Casein is a slow-digesting protein and contains branch chain amino acids (BCAA’s). One serving of Casein also contains almost half of the daily recommended value of Calcium.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Glutamic Acid HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
A deficiency of Glutamic Acid can lead to a number of issues. While this supplement is not intended to treat, cure or prevent any disease, it may be beneficial in maintaining mental wellness.

L-Glutamic Acid HCL is also used as a food seasoning, recognized for its savory umami taste and ability to enhance the flavor of otherwise bland dishes. This substance should not be confused with monosodium glutamate (MSG), which is chemically produced and toxic in larger quantities.

DescriptionData.Title: Hydrolyzed Whey Protein Isolate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Whey is a very rich source of protein, which accounts for 80% of its total weight. This protein powder is a rich source of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs). Leucine is the branched-chain amino acid that is primarily responsible for initiating protein synthesis in the body.

DescriptionData.Title: Alpha Lipoic Acid (ALA) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: ALA also assists in recycling various other antioxidants and may contribute to increased energy levels.

DescriptionData.Title: Choline L-Bitartrate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although it is not actually a B vitamin, it is sometimes considered to be a part of this complex because it operates in conjunction with various types of B vitamins. It is believed to have better bioavailability than its DL counterpart.

DescriptionData.Title: Spirulina (Organic) Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
Due to the environment that this algae is usually found in, it is able to absorb both the rich amino acids and all of the vitamins present in the water, compacting them all in the form of a single-celled organism that can then be consumed to reap those benefits.

As a bonus, Spirulina acts as a great source of Vitamin B12, essential fatty acids, Beta Carotene, and Chlorophyll. Some of these elements are only present in high amounts in the diets of meat eaters, and other nutrients like Beta-Carotene and Chlorophyll act as antioxidants and are useful in helping the body get rid of toxins.

DescriptionData.Title: Choline L-Bitartrate Capsules
DescriptionData.Description: Although it is not actually a B vitamin, it is sometimes considered to be a part of this complex because it operates in conjunction with various types of B vitamins. It is believed to have better bioavailability than its DL counterpart.

DescriptionData.Title: Resveratrol (Pure) Capsules
DescriptionData.Description: The most popular Resveratrol supplements that can be bought today are usually using Resveratrol derived from Japanese Knotweed. This represents one of the best original sources for extraction, since it contains the substance in such high amounts.

DescriptionData.Title: L-Carnitine L-Tartrate Powder

DescriptionData.Title: L-Carnitine Fumarate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Carnitine is considered conditionally essential, meaning that there are certain conditions a person can undergo which might make supplementation or dietary changes necessary to keep up Carnitine levels.

Moringa leaves (in addition to the pods and seed of the plant) are also known to possess anti-inflammatory properties, which may help ease joint pain. For more information on a number of Moringa Leaf's benefits, individual research is always encouraged.

DescriptionData.Title: Cranberry Extract 4:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Cranberries are low in sodium and do not contain cholesterol or fat.

DescriptionData.Title: Fenugreek Powder

DescriptionData.Title: HMB Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Ginger Root Extract Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Creatine Monohydrate (Instant) Powder

DescriptionData.Title: White Kidney Bean Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Blueberry Extract 4:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although both blueberries and blueberry extract are used for a number of health benefits, this product is intended to promote overall health only.

DescriptionData.Title: Bee Pollen Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
In addition to its inclusion in many dietary supplements, Bee Pollen powder is also used in skin-softening powders and lotions.

How is Bee Pollen harvested?

Beekeepers will frequently attach small boxes to the hive entrances, affixed with screens. When the bees pass through, the pollen is removed from their legs. They are not harmed in this process, and the keepers are careful to avoid collecting too much pollen from one hive at a time.

DescriptionData.Title: Berberine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: The added hydrochloride is intended to help along the absorption and digestion process. Berberine can be applied topically to the skin as well for burns.

DescriptionData.Title: Horny Goat Weed Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Echinacea Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Holy Basil Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Galla Chinensis Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Creek Yellow Grass Extract Powder

DescriptionData.Title: L-Pyroglutamic Acid Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Although this nutrient is naturally occurring in a few food groups, it can only be found in small amounts, often making supplementation preferable.

DescriptionData.Title: Bitter Melon Extract 4:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Bitter Melon comes from the Cucurbitaceae family, which includes squash, cucumber, watermelon and more. It is described as being one of the most bitter of the culinary vegetables or fruits, but is lauded for its benefits.

DescriptionData.Title: Rosehip Powder
DescriptionData.Description: In addition to its high antioxidant content, Rosehip Powder also serves as a natural anti-inflammatory.

DescriptionData.Title: Passion Flower Extract 4:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This supplement is standardized to contain no more than 10% dextrin, a water-soluble thickening agent.

DescriptionData.Title: Papaya Seed Powder
DescriptionData.Description: In addition to its unique benefits, Papaya Seed powder has been used to season food.

DescriptionData.Title: Papaya Fruit Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Organic Wheat Grass Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Motherwort Extract 5:1 Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This specific species of Motherwort is intended to promote cardiovascular, mental and optical health.

DescriptionData.Title: Horse Chestnut Extract Powder
DescriptionData.Description: This supplement also promotes digestive and circulatory health.

DescriptionData.Description: Not having enough Vitamin D3 in your system can lead to a deficiency. Vitamin D also aids the absorption of magnesium, another mineral essential to good growth.

DescriptionData.Title: Magnesium Orotate Powder

DescriptionData.Title: Caffeine (Synthetic) Capsules
DescriptionData.Description: This synthetic Caffeine powder is a particular kind of stimulant called Trimexylxanthine, which is a part of the larger Xanthine family. These are naturally occurring and are found in a few different plants. Some of the most common sources of Caffeine are in sports drinks, energy drinks, tea, coffee, chocolate and most soft drinks.

DescriptionData.Title: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C) 100 Mesh Powder
DescriptionData.Description:
HEALTH BENEFITS PROVIDED BY ASCORBIC ACID POWDER

For the many benefits of Vitamin C, consumers are encouraged to do their independent research.

DescriptionData.Title: Hordenine HCL Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Because Hordenine has been shown to increase the body's metabolism and help burn off fatty acids, it has become popular among athletes and is frequently included in preworkout stacks. It does not have the same "jittery" effects as caffeine.

DescriptionData.Title: Inulin (FOS) Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Also known as a fructooligosaccharide (acting as a prebiotic), inulin has about 10% the sweetness of sugar/sucrose. Inulin has also been used as a flour substitute in baked goods and a fat substitute in margarine. Natural inulin is frequently found in foods such as onions, garlic, bananas and wheat. This particular inulin supplement is derived from artichoke.

DescriptionData.Title: Soy Protein Isolate Powder
DescriptionData.Description: Isolate is considered the most "pure" type of protein, standardized to contain at least 90% pure protein. Because much of the carbohydrates are removed during this process, the soybean taste is less potent (making it ideal for more mixing and varied consumption).
